condition propounded luther melticius others better write waye submission would refuse nothing appertained reconcilement first therfore required aduersaries might kepe silence raile vpon secondarely driuen recante bounden interprete scripture prescript doctrine gospell bringeth libertie myndes men bounden within certen limites thynges may graunted content thinge lyeth nowe ende strife vnderstande matter commaunde either partie silence herein must chiefely beware flatterats must eschewed flatterer deafe eare sayle besydes theyr songes enticementes daungerous rockes sirenes ascribe vnto godlines affirme head world preferring aboue generall counselles nothing pestiferous kynde parasite credite rather admonishe dewtie put remebraunce part true frende man dewtie frende finally dedicateth booke lately written christen libertie commendinge fewe wordes conteyned summe trew doctrine begynning springe time themperour taketh shippinge spaine sayle englande royally receiued kynge henry eight maried hys aunte katherine amonges kyndes princelike liberalite builded goodlye lodginge purposely vpon riuer themse called bridewell then sayled flaunders ioyefully receyued almen time duke fridericke fell sore sicke wherfore luther compiled boke coforte letter saith comaundemet christ luth boke duke saronie amonges workes charitie whiche oughte one another shoulde also comforte sicke therfore many cause greatly bouden vnto sake gathered litle boke beyng otherwise able comfort signifiyng like man body head ake greueth rest membres taking apperteine priuatly euery nowe lieth sicke people oute iuste cause teares mournyng greatest part germany doth depede vpon reuerence chiefe ornament refuge afterwarde maketh booke confession teacheth confession synnes ought leane trust confessio promise god whiche forgeueth oure sinnes firste muste confesse v vnto god confesseth muste hate sinne couet amend life therehersall euery sinne particularly necessary possible performed wt diuers thing last vowes wherof wrote seueral work afterwardes certaine boke said thought expedient authority counsel might permitted men shuld receiue supper vnder bothe kindes whole supper vse speke vnder kindes saying contrary decree last counsel laterane offend many among others ihonbishop misene co maunded taught throughoute dioces whole supper comprised vnder one kinde condemned luther boke whiche thing vnderstanding maketh answer sort layeth fault thereof bishop certaine vnlearned troublesome person vnto whome saith wishe decre might made counsell deserued iust reprehension wisshed decree counsell wishe pope pius might lawfull pristes haue wiues whiche pius seconde bishoppe rome saide wished wherefore oughte blamed wishyng graunteth decree counsell laterane yet neuertheles contrarye fyrst eldest counselles aunciente maner churche agayne dispraise men boheme receaue vnder bothe kyndes wheras kepe v one halfe onely yet haue make institution christe maner obserued churche apostels time til late day haue nothing aledge counsel laterane whiche lighte verye weake reason maner cousel yt wel knowen euen laughed romanes selues thoughe neuer greate aucthoritie yet counsell latherane muche proue thinge reason antiquitie mockery concernyng counsell laterane thus iulius seconde elected byshoppe promysed solemne othe two yeares space holde generall counsell yere lorde thousande fyue hundreth three whilest made warre one frenche kynge another uenetians nowe duke farrare nowe others troubled italy nine cardinalles departed came millan called general counsel pisa counsell citie pisa xix day may yere lorde thousande fiue hundreth eleuen begynne kalendes september folowyng chiefest bernardinus cruceius william preneste fraunces cossentine wyth whome annexed ambassadours emperor maximilian lewes frenche king intended counsell depose bishopprike got briberye nowe muche broken othe bene bishoppe many yeres called counsel pourposed could suffer christian common weale lenger deluded letter coulde saufly conueighed vnto set vp townes italy admonishinge appeare parson daye appoynted iulius vnderstandynge matter maketh answere fyrst august time cardinall desyred nothing generall counsell whiche well knowen kinges prince whole college cardinal euen cause alexader syxt sore offended still minde also howe state italy hath late yeres bene troublesome lefte byshoppe alexander coulde counsell called suche aduersitie time cofuteth appoyntment shortnesse time discommoditie place pise towne torne defaced warres former yeres countrie aboute layde waste neyther men safely repayre thither reason warres betwixte florentine seue moreouer howe haue none authoritie call theyr cause alledged vntrewe wherefore commaundeth vnder paine excommunicatynge man obeye called counsell agaynste nexte yeare begynne rome vpon ninetenth daye aprill churche laterane pope shifie vnto subscribed one twentie cardynalles saye euer byshoppes policie afrayde counsell appoyncte place mete theyr purpose warneth cardinalles agaynste hym leaue theyr enterprise come rome offerynge pardon would come bannished xxiiij octobre namely thre spake heretykes scisinatykes traitours sendynge copie theyr prescription maximilian alother kinges many byshoppes fraunce ioyned selues cardinalles bannisheth also vnlesse forsake within certeine tyme make p gation againe cardinal diuerse time rised counsell vaine sytten eyght tymes suspends al well ciuill ecclestasticall iurisdiction commaunding ingenerall hereafter obey hym thys yeare lorde thousande fyue hundred twelue one twentye aprill tyme pauie philippe decius euntian excellently well learned set forthe booke defence cardinalles cause againste byshoppe rome afterwardes maximilian forsakyng cardinal made league iulius fardinando kinge spaine sent counsell rome mathew lang byshoppe gurce sametime made cardinal lewes kynge fraunce persisted styll purpose lately ouerthrowen bishop armye bauenna striken thonderbolte cursing hys realme gyuen ouer spoyled sytten counsell fyue tymes died xxi daye february yeare fraunce offered spoile lorde thousande fyue hundred thyrtene leo tenth dyd succede continewed counsel restored cardinal theyr former dignitie counsell ended xvi daye marche yeare lord mdxvij counsell debated rome doubt immortalitie soule turkishe warre reformation churche immortalitie soule doubted rome howe boheme shoulde reduced theyr errours whiche thynge luther speaketh receyued vnder bothe kyndes whilest thinges done saxonie diuines louain collen condemne luther workes written syluester prierias also penaunce excommunication indulgence preparation luth bookes condemned louaine vnto death prophane wicked worthy brente aucthor compelled recante whiche thynge beyng knowen luther aunswereth euerye article doctrine preface lamenteth theyr state condition time capnio rewcline condemned capnio yet hope nowe seyng endeuour extinguishe clere lyght doctrine ghospell growe euery day wourse god doubtles must nedes greuously offended case shoulde thus procede man bridle lybertie would shortely condemne bokes scripture decree liste theyr owne pleasure thinge considereth thinke lesse eyther antichrist doth reigne el come shortly theyr doctrine conteyneth sounde certen thynge waueringe diuers opinion saieth moreouer willia ockam time paste also condemned uniuersitie paris ockam receiued set bye lykewyse picus mirandula lawrens ualla whyche picus mirandula lawrence ualla nowe estimation moreouer sayeth iewes tymes paste peculiare people god fledde lyghte ghospell refused benefyte christ forsaken gaue place gentyles lykewyse nowe dayes byshoppes diuines chalenge take vpon greatest authoritie churche haue dede thinge elles vayne title others farre lyke ostentation ryghtely maye chalenge name brieflye howe haue thus vexed tymes good well learned men yet dyd neuer contende wyth wyth anye sounde trewe reason rather disceipte crafte tyranye dyd iohn husse hierome prage memory wherof shal endure euer marueleth rashenes ware many example blemishe selues uniuersities euer althoughe neuer sure grounde alledged neuer stronge reason agaynst famouse men yet touching matter haue dealt bothe wickedly maliciously ought offended might haue considered parte man haue vsed certen leuitie iudginge hys doctrine moued fury co demne althinges without respecte herein bewrey theyr maliciouse myndes spitte oute poyson theyr hatred make great accompt aristotle defende soeuer sayeth neuer contrary religion make aristotle excuse glo e depraue worckes agaynste charitie consonant trweth declare malicious cankred hertes oughte fyrste haue shewed faulte admonishynge gently haue reformed might haue proceded christ hath gyuen commaundement nowe small iuiurie byshoppe rome condempne boke dedicated vnto certeine preiudice reproue negligence newes maruell committee suche faulte agaynste bishoppe seynge moste malapartely contemne lawes god wylliam ockam speaketh flourished tyme emperour lewes fourth aboute yeare oure lorde willia ocka thousande three hundred twentie amonges thinges wrote power bishoppe rome boke handleth eight question diuerslye whether office highe bishoppe emperor may executed one parson whether themperor hath authoritie god also bishop rome whether christ gaue aucthoritie bishop church rome co mit themperor prince iurisdiction whether yt emperor beyng chosen hathe thereby full aucthoritie gouerne common wealth whether kynges besydes emperour kynge romanes much crowned priestes receyue anye aucthoritie wherfore kinges subiection suche inueste whether vsed newe ceremony crowned themselues lose regall power whether election seuen prince geue muche authoritie emperour doth lawfull succession kynges debatyng manye reason partes determineth comonly ciuile maiestrate vpon occasion mentionynge iohn two twenteth byshoppe name lyuynge made lawes extrauagauntes terme placed wyth canon lawe whiche saieth ockam reprehended many altogether false full heresyes recyteth errours maruelynge men witte geue credit howe beit tyme saieth paule wrote timothe moste parte men nowe day seke doctrine christe apostle auncient father hearken byshoppe rome willeth commaundeth concernyng capnio rewcline thus standeth matter iohn phefercorne iewe professed christianitie sued long emperour maximilian bookes iewes myghte abolished wicked full superstition hynderaunce conuerted christianitie therefore shoulde suffered kepe none bible maximilian length commaundeth uriel archebyshoppe mentz shoulde appointe certeyne uniuersities iames hogostrate inquisitour iohn reucline searche consult story reuchliue whether mete expedient oure religion excepte bybles bookes shoulde burned yere lorde thousande fiue hundred ten reuchline lawier right skilful hebrewe tongue receiued archbishoppes letter wrote againe mynde said hebrewes bokes three sortes history hebrew bokes thre sortes bookes phisicke prophecy laste also dyuers sortes whiche albeit many fonde supersticiouse thinges yet purpose profytable serue well confute errours dotage opinion sente archebyshoppe sealed phefercorne knewe made lytell doe set oute booke agaynste callinge hym fautoure defendour iewes reuchline defence estimation aunswereth another offended certein vniuersities especially collen moste reputation iames hogostrate arnolde togre wrot inuectiue like case phefercorne done dedicating ye theperor maximilia wente lawe archebyshoppe mentz hogostrate plaintife whome reuchline ennemy resused first aunswered vlatter attourney fine came self mentz accompanied diuers gentleman learned men whiche ulriche duke wirtemberge sent soughte meanes haue quieted matter coulde appealeth vnto rome bysshoppe rome committeth hearyng therof george palatine bishop spire commaunding el shoulde medle notwithstandyng colon condened reuchlines boke burned moneth february yere mdxiiij bishoppe spire take maruelous euil part plaintife beynge called seuerall tymes maner appered geueth sentence reucline approuynge booke good condemneth hogostrate costes domage intent make sentence frustrate trauayleth rome meane time fellowes home labored wrot paris lewis frenche kinge mediation erarde marchiaue byshoppe liege tyme greate lewis twelfeth wherofore uniuersitie paris longe debatynge matter condempned booke also worthye burnte author dryuen recant hebrew bokes brent like maner haue bene time past auguste followynge duke wirtemberge intreated letter reucline selfe wrote vnto gentely bene studiet sent copie sentence pronounced bishoppe spire vaine hogostrate sued rome three yeres could preuaile retourneth home againe wente diuers cardinalles vnto whome leo committed hearynge matter loued reuchline intierlye hys excellente learnynge amonges others adrianus wrote booke latin tounge also commended vnto erasmus roterodame whose epistle hys behalfe yet remaine menne louaine hadde publyshed theyr sentence luther tooke theyr aduise adriane cardinall derthuse spayne hollander borne brought vp amonges louaine whome boldned wherefore luther manye greate ennomyes luther letter emperor wrote epistle newlye created emperoure charles fifte fyrste crauynge pardone beinge manne lowe degree shoulde attempt write highe prince saithe matter weightye causeth doe altogether suche appertaineth glory christ signifying written certaine bokes whiche procured displeasure manye desert broughte contention aduersaries agaiust wikhe muche rather haue setten still hath bene chief studye pure doctrine go spell might appere false tradition men many good excellent learned men beare witnes cause hatred disdaine reproches pearils displesures hath bene thre yeres done much lay matter might taken vp oftner sought quietnes aduersaries offended hath oftentimes required shew wherin erred teach better thinges hitherto haue aunswered maner nothing railing wordes cruell iniuries sekinge quench doctrine gospell cause constrained vse last remedy ensamples athanasius flie vnto succour besechynge take vpon tuition christian doctrine defende againste violence iniurie till matter knowen desyre defence case proued maynteyne euill cause desyreth onely thing may tried knowen nothing determined apperteineth office cause hath highe power geuen god minister iustice mainteine right equitie defende pore weake agaynst iniuries stronger like effect writeth state empire reciting fewe wordes howe vnwillynge fall contention howe desyrous hathe bene haue taken vp condition hath offered yet doeth longe writeth luth letter archbishop metz archebishop mentz cardinall greate submission beynge sory saieth complained vpon suche wont praise doinges admonisheth gyue credit talebearer beware flatterer example kynge dauid disceaued flatteter siba would set part sinistrall suspicion workes vntill suche time leasure reade selfe two kindes men condemned writinge one neuer red another suche read dede malicious minde depraue doynges wherin man coulde fynde errour teache better woulde glad folowe hathe oftentymes protested asmuche trusted well great humanitie borne brought vp prouince hath cure coulde write thus vnto hym cardinall aunswered againe pleased well asmuch promised defende doynges obstinatelye annswere luther would willyngly gyue place vnto suche coulde reache better thinges albeit delighted muche religion yet leasure hitherto reade workes therfore would iot iudge leaue vnto others taken thinge hande neuerthelesse would wishe bothe expositours scripture handle euery thing reuerently modestly without scripture must hadled reproche enuie sory heare men dispute openly supremacie byshoppe rome frewill supper lorde suche question full daunger part could contente learned men conferre matter frendly amonges selues would blame teaching truth done without bitternesse contempte ecclesiasticall power professe trueth good zeale continewe presumpsion malice permanent longe endure abuseth god giftes heapeth vp doubtlesse sore vengeaunce vpon selfe luther wrote also bishoppe mersebourge thing luth letter bish oy merseburge effecte touching doctrine clere conscience taught none thinge christ apostle maners lyfe aunswere professyon wisheth remoued office preaching seketh lucre desyreth vaine glory thing onely euerlastyng veritie myght knowen men condemne workes moued maruelous hatred abuse byshop rome name fulfyll owne affection whereas many learned men foren nation haue writtin letter reioysyng writinges geuing thankes whervpon beleueth rather hath taught sounde doctrine wherfore requireth deale fatherly shewe faulte way hitherto coulde obteyne muche matter might hearde notwithstandyng hath aunswers luther ernest prayer required also man greater pleasure take errour whereunto bishop aunswereth hath bene oftentimes carefull litell sory hath written amonges others boke lordes supper wherwith many sore offended people vnder cure greatly inflamed doctrine chiefly sory reprehendeth sharpenes writing saith albeit straungers like yet allow wisheth woulde bringe christian minde voide affection handlinge matter furthermore chargeth haue spoken vnreuerently bishop rome thing neither becometh mete suffered wherefore admonisheth applye dexteritie wit dthirthynges may profit common wealth leaue thys bitter contention last al requireth error may shewed promiseth tractable saith answer therto wryting au time shal mete wil talk large duke fridericke time certaine rtes rome commended ualentine ditleb germane sent worde matter well hearde rome reason rashnes leud demener luther written many thinges bitterly spitefully againste bishop church rome college cardinal fellow nourished maintained moste men affirmed whan duke receiued letter aunswereth neuer intent defende luther doctrine maintenaunce neither dothe take vppon iudgement thinges luther teacheth heareth dede doctriue well allowed learned men iudge therof hath long since made offer may haue sure sauf conduicte rendre reason doctrine bishoppes legate euer hys error shewed moste ready forsake hys opinion thus hathe protested openlye althoughe thys myghte appeare sufficient yet admonished hym long sence wold haue forsaken country charles meltice aduised contrary thought better remaine stil go place perauenture hauing libertye mighte setforth worse thinges hitherto hath done wherfore iust cause alledged suspect euil trusteth fare neuer worse bishop handes therfore wold right hartely sory erroure spronge vp time shoulde said defended established deuiseth wt familiarely howe contention began reason eckius others excellent wittes good learning knowledge toges florishe nowe germanye desire common people haue read scripture luther doctrine infixed many men mindes vsed otherwise well like styrre vp suche tumultes germany turne nother bishop el profit duke thus written kalends aprill receiued vi day iuly letter bishop rome wherin reioysed little wold haue nothing wyth luther wicked man affirming euer good opinion forasmuch graue haue aduouched true good wil bare hereby little encreased thing doth rightwel become hys house hath euermore done great honor church rome singulare wisdome doth also herein appeare perceiueth sente christe sathan ennemye almankinde whiche mad kinde ambition reyseth vp agayne heresyes wiclife husse condemned whiche seeketh fauoure people vayne glorye whichs false enterpretatio scripture giueth simple occasion sinne dispiseth chastitie speaketh againste confession penaunce beareth fauoure turkes raileth discipline church lamentech punishemente heretikes briefe turneth thinges vpside growen pride arrogancie contemning aucthoritie counselles bishoppes rome woulde haue hys owne oppinion take place iudgement wherfore wittely done haue familiarytie pestilent fellowe alowe hys errour whiche thinge graue wise men muche commende vertue chieflye giueth god hertie thankes hath giuen suche mynde affirming moreouer hath suffered borne rashenes see woulde amende asmuche hathe nothinge preuailed gentle admonishmentes compelled vse extreme remedy fearyng lest throughe contagion shoulde infecte many wherfore callyng counsel cardinalles learned men debate matter hath made decree instinction holy spirite whiche neuer faileth churche rome copie wherof hath sent vnto intent might see monstrouse errours minister sathan pope curseth luther defendeth wilieth therfore vnlesse openly solemnely recant daye prescribed commit toward shall put away shame house germany wynne muche honor god highe seruice decree ouerlonge summe fyrst byshoppe leo callynge vpon christe peter paule sainctes tourne awaye daunger hangynge ouer bulle leo church lamentably complayneth spring vp doctrine conteinyng bothe heresy already condemned also newe errours great wickednes germany wont muche churche rome bothe longe sin late dayes concernyng husse boheme numbre christian throughout vniuersall worlde committed vnto charge christ lenger wyncke great matter reciting luther opinion saieth christian charitie reuerens men owe duetie churche rome agaynste counsell aunciente father wherfore consent cardinalles condemneth work brought forth burned aucthoritie whiche saieth hath commaundeth magestrates namelye germany se thing executed accordingely commeth luther shewyng howe fatherly loue sought refourme howe cited rome promised beare charge howe contempte therof appealed cou sell contrary decree pius iulius decree pius iuli hereby deserued punishement condigne heretikes yet clementie gyue longer time happely prodigal child amended owne misery would retourne bosome churche yet also minde yea moste hertely besecheth adherentes trouble church promysing great good wyll cease theyr errours notwithstandynge commaundeth luther teache prescribynge lx dayes wythin whiche time shoulde amende burne owne bokes recante doctrine openlye condemneth heritike suffer accordynge yt lawes suspendeth church commaunding al men eschew talke company vnder lyke penaltie decree red church assembly people certen dayes appointed touching pius iulius thus standeth pius hilde counsell mantua yeare lord mcccclix chiefely turkisshe warre amonges made decree man appeale byshoppe counsell vnder coope heauen said coulde nothinge founde better christes uicar longe suspended sigismunde duke austriche takinge cardinall cusane prisoner duke appealed counsell wherfore byshoppe excommunicate george heimburge worker herof commaunding senate norinburge banishe citie spoile goodes whiche decree renewed iuly maynteyne selfe agaynst cardinalles swarued agaynst kynges prince vniuersitie paris whiche vsed ofte suche refuge bishop pius called aeneas siluius counsell basill wrot aeneas siluius euery thing praysing decree made exceadyngly auaunced highe degree dignitie chau ged opinion would haue counsell subiecte byshop honor chage maners luther hearde condemned rome goeth former appellation wherin appealed bishoppe counsell nowe forsomuche byshoppe perseuerynge hys luth impugneth pope censure wicked tyrrannye hath proceded farre condemne nether called heard yet conuicte heresye saieth howe appealeth againe counsel chiefly foure cause hath condemned pleasure hearyng controuersie comaundeth denie faith sacramentes necessary preferreth owne decree dotage men scripture leaueth place anye counsell wherefore calleth tyrran proude contemner churche fynallye antichriste affirmynge shewe proue al thinges whensoeuer shall please superiours therfore prayeth themperour magistrate accepte appellation defence god glory libertie counsell would bridell tyrranny thynke decree made concerned nothynge would styrre nothinge tyll cause lawfully decided thus appealed xvij day nouembre written boke captiuitie babilon preface luth booke captiuitie babilou wherof saieth howe profiteth dayely knowledge holy scripture howe fewe yeares paste set forth booke byshoppes pardon tyme wrote renerently stoode great feare romisshe tyrranny great estimation iudgement farre otherwise beynge styrred vp prouocation aduersaries hath lerned see rome nothynge el kyngdome babilon power stronge hunter niutroth afterwardes disputeth sacramentes churche holdeth three onelye baptisme penaunce lordes thre sacrases supper treateth also foure confirmation order matrimonye unction calleth sacramentes haue sygnes annexed promesse sacramentes properly called sacrament haue promise ioyned saith vare signes therfore thinketh penaunce couted numbre wil properly exactly speake accordyng difinition word wateth visible signe heauely institutio yt hard bishop decre besides appellation mentioned setforth tha another work wherin confirmed mayteyned opinion whiche leo condemned meane time emperor flaunders hauinge set thinges ordre appointeth prince electours mete acon sixte daye octobre inuested priuces arritsing collen ten mile acon heard sore plage wherevpon wrote emperour beynge tyme louaam woulde chouse place townes melt whiche bestowed great coste preparyng theyr house victualles wordes extenuate force plage encouraginge come wherfore emperour perceuereth styll mynde saying lightly alter breake law charles forth thus ordeined wherefore xxi daye octobre come thirther three archebyshoppes menty collen treuers ambassadours duke saxonie marque bra denburge duke saxonie lay sicke collen next daye rode forthe mete emperour lyghting theyr horse receiued honorably mouthe lorde mentz answereth gently cardinal salisburge thus ioynynge together marched towardes towne gate mete paulsograue prince elector thousande syre hundred horse demy launce archer emperour two thousand al gorgeous apparell iohn duke cleaue foure hundred horseman fayre armed contended muche saxon whether go muche prease beyng great company fayre many suche lyke hath bene seldome sene germany night came vpon could entre towne eyther syde emperour rode archebishoppe collen mentz next folowed ambassadour kynge boheme also cardinal sedune salisburge croye ambassadours kynges prynces ambassadour byshoppe rome kinge englande onely absent whiche thought done set porpose lest goinge prince germany seme diminishe dignitie sent emperour broughte oure lady churche made hys prayer talked thelectors part went lodgyng next daye met againe church suche prease people haruesed men muche kepe backe middes churche hangeth large crowne floore vnderneth covered clothe arras vpon themperour maner coronatio laye downe gruflynge whilest lorde collen said ouer hym certaine prayer whiche ended archeby shoppes mentz treuers toke vp led ladyes anltar falleth downe agayne sayd praiers led seate fayre gilted tharchebishoppe collen goeth masse litle proceded demaudeth latin whether wil kepe catholicke faith defende church ministre iustice restore empire defende widowes fatherles others distresse whether gyue dewe reuerence bishop rome hath assented led vnto aultar taketh othe vpon retourneth seate againe archebishoppe collen asketh prince whether perfourme gyue theyr faythe allegeaunce whiche thing promised againe certein praiers finished annointeth brest head boughtes armes palmes hades done archebishoppes mentz treuers lead reustry apparelled like deacon bring agayne chayre prayer sayde collen accompanied wyth two delyuereth hym sworde drawen commendeth vnto common wealth againe puttinge vp sworde skabarde putteth also rynge fynger aboute roobe royalle moreouer reacheth hym scepre appell golde representynge shape rounde worlde three archebishoppes together set diademe vpon hys head led aultare sweareth agayne wil dewtye good prince afterwardes followe conueing vp higher place set seate stone tharchebishoppe mentz speakyng vulgare tounge wisheth great prosperitie commendynge vnto moste diligently selfe peres state empire likewise prebendes churche chosen f lowe colledge olde custome done organes trompetes blow vp myrthe melody thynges behelde lady margarate aunte yt egent flaunders whan masse done themperour receiued lordes supper dubbed many knyghtes willyng honor time past wont gyuen onely suche foughten manfully agaynst theyr enemy rewarde valeauntnes nowe maner kynges swordes drawen shall strike softely shoulder desyre ordre whether nobilitie marchauntes couet honour churche came palace sumptuously hanged arayed emperoure dined electours also euery man selfe hall diuers table set eche syde emperours table archebishoppe treuers placed right ouer themperor accordyng lawe charles fourth day auncient custome roosted whole oxe farsed wyth beastes piece whereof serued emperours table rest haue common people moreouer day runne two conduictes wyth wyne free men diuer theperor retornyng lodging deliuereth tharchbishop mentz ye seales thempire next day maketh supper prince electours daye folowed reparynge churche hearde masse worshipped reliques sainctes amonges others say cloth sauioure lapped swaddlynge cloutes archbyshop mentz pronounceth bishop rome approuynge creation doeth commaunde hereafter vse name cesar electours beyng departed contagious place cesar taketh also iourney arriueth collen aboute fyrste nouembre whence sendyng letter throughe germany calleth assemblie empire wormes agaynste syxte daye ianuarye themperor calleth cou sel imperial concernyng archebishop mentz spake howe bishoppe rome confyrmed emperours creation thus haue tourned totnam frenche late yeres tymes past bishoppes rome wonte approued themperours pore encreased wealth onely begyn rule theyr pleasure also length brought vnto passe muche strife contention dede pope subiecte themperor permitted seuen prince germany might electe hym saye lyeth theyr power onely cofirme ratifie authoritie haue vsed many tymes maner throughe realmes chiefly italy fraunce germany tyme haue put downe kynges substituted others theyr place besides place canon lawe thepistles decretall gregory ix innocentius iij affirmeth aucthoritie chosyng themperor benefit bishoppes churche rome conueighed grekes germanes tyme great charlemaigne howe theyr partes know iudge whether person mete yet coteted haue also extorted faithe othe highest magistrate whole vniuersall worlde whiche thynge hathe bene often tymes cause great warres muche mischief fyne clemet lawe clement fift bounde lawe lyued yere lorde thousande thre hundred wheras henry seuenth emperour name house lucemburge woulde thys sort bounden said matter newly inuented neyther vsed former time clemet come openeth matter large declarynge othe conteyned say themperour shoulde defende church rome banish heretikes haue company wicked al meanes possible mayneteine dignitie bishoppes rome yt defend kepeal priuiledges grauted church rome tyme especially geuen costantine charlemaigne henry otto fourth fridericke secod rodulphe chalenge parte landes possession church rome maner title pretence thinges saith emperour bounden henry also messenger promised hym lesse howe soeuer dissembled afterwarde thys decree came forth death emperour henrye clement first called forth cardinal fro rome lyon kept court fraunce syns whiche time courte rome fraunce authoritie power emperours hathe decreased italy daylye power dignitie bishoppes bene augmented much dayes lytle time emperours haue supposed owe faithe obediens euen bounden dewtie chiefe bishoppes yt haue molested oure emperours gregory seuenth ix alexandre thyrde innotentius thyrde fourth nicolaus thyrde bonisace eyght clement fyste nowe let v retourne pourpose meane tyme cefar yet collen byshoppe rome sent marinus carracciolus hierome aleander encense duke saro incensed againste luther duke saxonie againste luther speakynge fyrste praise familie tellynge daunger haged ouer germany deuilishe workes luther demaunded fine two thinges firste would commaunde bokes caste fyre secondarelye woulde eyther see hym executed send bounde rome peter bonhomme tergeste barnarde trent bishoppes also commission cesar prince germany beyng required ayde accomplishe byshoppes request committed sayde aleander doctor eckius herynge matter duke fridericke matter importaunce axynge tyme deliberation fourth daye nouembre answer duke friderike maketh aunswere hys counsell hym selfe otherwise occupied presence bishoppe trent howe farre beyonde expectation bishoppe rome shoulde demaunde anye suche thynge hathe alwayes indeuoured selfe nothing vnworthy vertue dignitie auncestours faithfull seruice empire dewe obseruaunce churche howe hath heard whilest hath bene fro home eckius hath gone bring trouble onely luther others also dominion cotrary order maner canon lawe whiche thinge righte taketh euil part priuate take vpo medle muche masiurisdictio luther others haue done absence sin byshoppes decre brought knoweth neuer thinge matter neyther nowe haue howebeit teache rightly sory two yere past labour meanes broughte cardinall caietaine auspurge spoken together coulde agree muche cardinall caietane wrote vnto hym letter complaint answered time thought satisfied yea take awaye suspicion would haue put luther miltitius letted matter moreouer howe oftener archbishop treuers appointed heare matter howe luther wyll appere place euer commaunded may assured maketh large great offer required opinion good well learned men hathe thus farre proceded owne accorde pricked forwarde aduersaries yet hath neyther bene heard emperor others workes conuicte hercsye ought burnt el would already haue done duetye good prince requireth therefore woulde deale sorte rather fynde meanes godlye learned menne maye chosen shall frendely quietlye heare whole matter luther maye haue good safeconduicte bookes burned hathe pleaded cause testimony scripture sownde argumentes conuicted holde hys doynges although bothe cause shoulde take foile yet woulde trust byshoppe would requyre nothyng might stande honoure thynges throughe god helpe would shoulde become prince empire obdient childe church tyme answere geuen deliberation began recite howe many thynges byshoppe rome done suffered luther mighte length retourne right way hath kepte parte promyse lyeth nowe archbishoppe treuers matter muche bishoppe rome hathe taken selfe onely apperteineth iudge suche cause conclusion theyr talke yt said must procede according bishoppes decree longe burned luther workes luther bokes br aleander italian borne right skilful hebrew tonge sometyme reader paris commynge rome grewe estimation first made archebistoppe brunduse cardinal degre dignitie came also carracciolus luther vnderstoode calleth forthe studentes wittenberge presens many learned men burneth luther burneth canon law byshop rome law decree lately published openly teth day decembre next day lecture admonisheth al men regarde theyr saluation beware bishoppes kyngdom afterwarde set forth boke wherin sheweth cause burned canon lawe first hath bene olde custome obserued time naughtie pestilent bokes burned testimony wherof yet actes apostle moreouer concerneth dewtie baptised christe whiche professour open teacher holye scripture impugne wycked doctrine teache men holesome plucke me mindes false erronious opinion apperteineth also many others although yt bryng letted eyther ignoraunce feare perill oughte yet none excuse vnlesse dewtie moreouer bishoppe rome rable obstiuate shamelesse onely wyll heare good admonition also condempne doctrine christ apostle compell men committe open idolatry furthermore supposeth howe booke burner booke burner haue commission burne bookes diuines collen louain emperour finally muche workes beyng burnt brute therof spread abroade ouer countreis many growe weaker doubtfull supposynge caste fyre withoute cause therefore dyd seynge aduersaries past remedy burne theyr bookes also might therby erecte confyrme mindes men wherfore besecheth men laying syde thambitiouse proude title aduersaries would looke nerer thinge howe wicked pestilent opinion conteyned bokes law thinge maye better perceyued innumerable hath gathered fewe thynges whiche belonge reproche almightie god iniurie ciuill magistrate establisshing owne tyranny numbre thyrtie place whereby sheweth iuste cause burne prouoketh shewe reason wherfore burnt workes cause fewe none haue diuerse age past attempted anithing agaynste tyrannye antichrist saieth hathe bene scripture hath prophecied howe shoulde destroy aduersaries haue kynges assist seyng therfore prophetes apostle haue tolde v suche tyrrible thynges come easye consydre howe greate behoueth hys crueltye commeth passe ordenarily worldly matter best begynnynge thinges procedeth worste ende whiche hathe proued diuerse example inuergeth agaynste citie rome whiche beyng indewed god many benefites ornamentes vtterly gone kynde contagion hathe infected great part world byshoppes ordinauce agaynst lawes agaynst good customes nether suffered fleeth lawful iudgement affirmeth selfe aboue lawes iudgementes tolde fyrste boke syluester prierias wrote agaynst luther whan answered sharpely ambrosius catarinus italian toke defende setting forthe booke dignitie bishoppe catarinus writeth lut rome whiche luther aunswereth large interpretynge certen place daniell teacheth byshoppes tyrrannye paynted proueth suche thinges hathe prophecied kyngdome antichriste altogether concerne see rome catarinus made archbyshoppe cossent thirde booke sleidanes commentary concerning state religion common weale empire charles fyfte argument thirde booke duke fridericke obteyneth letter safeconduict luther come wormes defende opinion writinges themperor state perseuereth constantly although themperor threateneth wyth banishment pope cursed hym bulle lordes supper prynces seuerally soughte peruerte counsell constaunce set eye vpon occasion mention made wyclese iohn hussc z ischa bohemer sorbonistes condempne luther bokes whilest pope frenche kynge made league swiss z wmglius diswadeth takyng pension luter beyng exiled letter patentes auoydeth kynge englande writcth agaynst pope leo dyeth adrian succedeth solyman greate turke hathe luckie successe hongary commotion spayne themperor couetyng appease treated wyth englande goeth thyther byshoppe constance persecuteth z wynglius trouble wittenberge annabaptistes aryse assemble norinberge pope sendeth thyther letter ambassadours turke taketh rhodes z winglius hauyng set forth hys doctrine certeyne article assayled papistes fyne ghospell receyued z uricke duke fridericke accompaniynge emperour emperour sent luther wormes assemblie wormes obteyned cesar sayde would call luther heare matter whiche luther vnderstanding duke letter wrote agayne aboute latter ende ianuary exceadyng glad emperor would vouche saufe heare matter dede common cause shalbe content thing may saufe consciece wherfore besecheth prouide may daunger good well learned men may chosen dispute condemned conuicte heresie meane time aduersaries may refraine theyr wonted rayling cease burnynge bookes case shall nede hereafter enterprise anye thinges el god glorye trouthes sake emperor impeched herin promisyng fayle come wormes whan shall haue receyued themperors sauffeconduit trusteth sorte demeane selfe cause indifferent iudges worlde may vnderstande hath done nothing rebellion common wealth chieflye germany haue taken al trauell reduce men many grosse errours sownde pure doctrine desyreth moreouer emperor woulde haue regarde horrible bondage miserable estate christientie oppressed throughe mere papistrie wherfore cesar collicted empe writeth luther duke wrote vnto luther syxte day marche muche setforth certeine bookes determined heare matter selfe prince wherfore signifie vnto hath free libertie passe repasse safely without daunger plainely doeth appere saufe conduict sent commaundeth therfore take iorney spedely fayle within one twentie dayes byshoppes rome haue accustomed thursedaye passion weeke solemnely curse banne certeine kyndes men bul cursyng fyrst heretikes secondarely pirate suche eyther reyse vp new customes extorte forboden also suche coutrefeit bulles iustrumentes courte rome moreouer sell armure turkes sarasyns suche vnlawfull ware let hinder corne brought rome hurt man suyng belongynge courte rome furthermore suche worke damage violence possessyons neighbour dominion churche rome namely citie rome sicilie naples cardinie corf hetruria spolete sabine ancona flaminie campanie bononie farrare beneuent perusie auenion former bishoppes haue named heretikes garasians pateronians pore menne lion arnoldistes speronistes wicleuistes hussite fratricelles leo teth put also lutherians curseth full blacke curse commonly called bull lordes supper luther got afterwardes translated duche without much myrthe pastime luther receued emperours letter went wormes heralt came almooste diuerse diswaded hym puttynge mynde howe bokes brent certen preiudice condemnation howe might chaunce ded iohn husse stoute courage contemned perill sayinge plainely deuyll woulde put thus feare seynge consta cie luth kingdome quayle confession trewth notable place came wormes syxt day april next day brought emperour whole counsell lut cometh wormes prince emperours commaundement eckius lawyer spake vnto wise two cause martin eckius luther luther whiche emperor consent prince state hath sent forth commaundyng enquire thee first wherther thou wilt acknowledge bookes thine made thee againe whether thou wilt reuoke thing stande defence written therin luther brought wt lawies wittenberge one hierome schurffe lu pleadeth cause themperour whole empire title bokes read shewed done luther briefly repeting question propouded concerning bookes saieth confesse acknowledge myne whether defende haue written intente make trewe aunswere nothyng rashely forsomuch thinge weightie importaunce require time take deliberation thing debated albeit saieth thou myghtest easely haue knowen emperours letter thou waste sent therfore nowshouldest seke delay answere yet cesar clemencie graunteth thee one dayto take aduisement commaunding thee time declare thou wilte herein mouthe writynge made delay many supposed would constant came next daye eckius sayde vnto yesterday thou wouldest aunswere seconde demaunde required time whiche myghte ryght well haue bene denied euery man ought certen fayth aunswere therto al time much lesse great diuine doubt premeditate answere euer matter sayest thou nowe wilt thou defend thine owne writinges luther addressyng aunswer emperor counsell prince besought heare paciently ought offende eyther wordes maners gesture vnsemely suche presens beare pardo kinde lyfes sake hath bene brought vp selfe saith witnesse nothinge el haue taughte syncerly hitherto thinges whiche beleue concerne glorye god saluation men concernyng bookes answered yesterday made written hath added thyng take mine secode question bokes haue wrytten sundrie argumentes apperteine onely doctrine fayth vertue whiche myne aduersaries selues commede abiure play parte honest man others wherein reprehended byshoppe rome hys doctrine whereby hath sore afflicted christian common wealth seeth pitifully men consciens vexed lawes decree deny howe craftely disceiptfully robbeth countreis chieflye germany maketh yet ende hys rauenynge abolishe bokes shoulde confyrme tyrrannye shoulde greater preiudice done nowe authoritie emperour prince thirde kynde written agaynste certeine priuate men whiche woulde defende romishe wickednes seke euery trap confesse haue bene vehement became ascribe selfe holines profession life maners trewe doctrine yet wyll retracte nothynge doyng set open windowe arrogancie manye yet would taken thoughe toke vpon could erre muche propertie man erre disceaued take defence cause saying sauior speakynge doctrine time striken seruat sayeth haue spoken euyll beare wytnesse euyll wherefore christ perfection refused witnes vile seruaunt iohn xviii howe muche synner nature come whan called man testifie bring forth thing doctrine wherfore desyre honour god haue thynge obiecte agaynste doctrine professe would hide come forth shew errour testimony scripture whiche thinge done lytell obstinate fyrst men shall caste myne owne bokes fyre hereby maye man iudge led rashely like one rauished wittes haue waied diligently weightines thinge trouble ingendred doctrine reioyse greatly wha perceyue doctrine cause great offence christ selfe saith nature gospell styrre vp strife contention euen amonges suche ioyned nere bloud nowe therfore noble men ye ought grauely greate deliberation consyder foresee leste condemnynge doctrine throughe syngular beuefyte god offred ye cause muche incouenience may therby chaunce vnto germany muste haue respecte also newe empire yonge emperor present made vnlucky vnfortunate vngodly vnprofitable example posteriti proued diuerse place scripture haue empire fallen greate peril tyme common wealth hath bene gouerned onely counsel man wisedome notwithstandyng wyse honourable prince myne intent shewe haue speake zeale beare germany natife cou trie ought derer vnto v oure owne lyues rest besethe receyue tuition protection agaynst forse myne enemyes tyme made ende eckius stowning comutenaunce sayd vnto thou answerest nothing purpose noyther thy part call agayne question thinges haue bene determined intimes past aucthoritie counsel thou shouldest make playne directe answere whether thou wilte abide thy writynges sayd luther asmuche commaud dement mightie cesar noble prince shall answere directly obey therfore myne aunswere vnlesse conuinced testimony holy scripture manifest reason reuoke parte whiche haue written taught neuer thynge hurte myne owne conscience bishoppe rome counsel onely beleue admitte authoritie haue erred pope cost sell may erre often tymes set forthe thinges contrary one another may erre disceaued prince layde theyr heades together touchyng aunswere sayd eckius thou aunswerest luther vnreuerently becommeth thee sufficientlye matter thy bookes thou makest difference case thou woulde retract conteyne greater part thyne errours cesar woulde suffer iniurie done vnto suche well written thou dispisest counsell constaunce wheras manye noble well learned men germany renewest errours therein condemned wilt conuinced holy scripture herein thou doest well art farre abused loke thinges church hath condemned maye come newe disputation euery man seke reason eche thinge speaketh counsell must reproued scripture shall nothyng certeinly determined whiche cause emperour wyll haue thee pronounce openly thou determinest thy bookes beseche saieth luther gyue leaue kepe conscience safe sounde haue answered playnely haue none thinge say vnlesse myne aduersaries shew trew argumentes taken scripture take away errour quiet minde able shew haue oftentimes shamefully erred swarue scripture whiche manifest cannot erre wicked dede sayd could proued euer generall counsel erred luther sayd could would departed time next day emperour sent letter prince syttyng counsell signifiyng progenitours professed christian religion euermore obeied church rome seing luther doth impugne perseueryng obstinately opinion hys dutie requireth folowynge steppe hys auncestours defende christian religion succor church rome wherfore wyll banishe luther adherentes vse fitte remedy quenche fyre touching promise kepe may retorne home agayne safe sound epistle muche debated skanned amonges prince saide promise kept according decree made counsel constance manye others namely lewes countie palatyne prince elector affyrminge would redounde perpetuall shame germany wherupon diuerse thought mete kepe theyr promise also condempne rasshelye weightie matter consyderyng themperor yeares soone moued exasperated agaynst luther byshoppe rome minister fewe dayes bishoppe treuers appoynteth luther come xxiiij daye aprill present joachin treuers prince threateneth luther marque brandenburge electour george duke saxonie byshop auspurge noble whan luther brought archebishoppes chapplaine emperours heraulte ueus lawyer badon sayde vnto noble prince haue sent thee martin luther enter disputation thee treate fredly thee priuatly admonishe thee touching thine owne profyt emperour hath geuen leaue fyrst may counsel haue taught dyuerse thinges contrary albeit haue erred yet theyr authoritie decaied herby euery man may treade vnder foote thy bokes well loked wyll styrre vp greate trouble many interprete thou hast written christen libertie theyr owne affection entent maye lyste worlde nowe corrupte hath bene tofore therfore men must worke warely thy workes reproued feared lest deuill meane tyme petswade thee set forth others agaynste religion godlines thy bokes may altogether condemned thou hast set forth last declare ryght well tree knowen fruites blosome thou art ignoraunt diligently scripture warneth v beware noone deuill fliynge arrowe enemye mankynde ceaseth lye waite v many time vnder godly pretence intrappeth leadeth v awaye errour therefore thou oughtest consider bothe thine owne saluation men would become thee foresee lest suche christ hath hys death redemed death euerlastynge beyng thy faulte bokes prechinges seduced churche perishe againe dignitie church men ought acknowledge reuerently world nothing better tha obseruation lawes lyke como weale consisteth wtout lawes euen vnlesse moste holy decree forefather reuerently kept shall nothing troublesome state church quiet stable noble vertuouse prince present singular zeale beare commo weale thy cause wealth also thoughte good admonisshe thee thinges doubtles thou wylte perseuer thus obstinatlye thine opinion relent emperour wyll bannishe thee empire wyll forbyd thee haue anye restynge place germany ende thou maiest better consyder thine owne state wherunto luther replied great good gentlenes luther answer prince noble prince shewed vnto gyue hertye thankes certenlye man baser sorte shoulde beseme noble men take suche paine concernynge counsel reprehende chiefly constaunce haue iuste cause husse defyned churche fellowshippe god electe bothe saying beleued holy churche condemned also worthy selues condemned spake bothe truely like christen man therfore suffer punishement yea spend life sooner swarue manifest worde god muste rather obey god men touching offence connneth bookes neyther ought eschewe offence charitie offenca faith maners faythe differ much wherof consisteth life maners must anye wyse auoyded thother whiche cleaueth godes worde regarded trewth commaundemet heauenly father must accomplished though whole world offended scripture calleth christ himselfe stone offence appertayneth also likewise suche preach gospell knowe ought obey lawes magistrate haue euermore taught people also writinges sufficiently beare witnes howe muche ascribe dignitie lawes touchyng decree churche consideration god word taught sincerely bishop pastours church dewtie like christ apostle haue ordeined nede impose vnto me mindes conscieces yt heauie intollerable burthe men traditios moreouer ignorat ye scripture admonisheth v refrain affectios thig truely spoken wilbe glad perfourme neither thinge obstinately may onely professe doctrine gospel whan sayd thus comaunded depart whan consulted matter ueus amonges thinges began perswade submitte writynges knowledge emperour prince content saith wil neuer seme refuse iudgemet cesar state thempire maye done scripture god worde whiche maketh much vnlesse reproue errour forsake mine opinion paule commaundeth beleue aungel comming heauen bringe doctrine wherfore besecheth prince might kepe saufe conscience theyr mediation emperour mighte obtayne content thing said marque bradenburge wilt thou geue place except thou conuict scripture dede saieth luther el manyfest reason wherfore counsell broken vp archbishoppe treuers toke parte began admonishe againe might preuaile next day also moued commit iudgement vnto cesar senate prince without conditio vaine noone bishoppe certeine others required lest submitte workes nexte generall counsell agreeth therunto matter handled aucthoritie scripture archbishop priuate talke alone demaunded remedy would helpe greuous disease sayde best counsell gamaliel tymes past gaue scribe phariseis contende god fyne coulde preuaile actes v letteth depart gently sayd would deuise retourne home saufeconduicte longe commeth eckius lawier saieth vnto asmuche thou hast refused admonishmentes cesar prince emperour hence forth office apperteineth commaudeth thee depart hence immediatly graunting thee one twentie dayes thy retourne looke promise made thee wil kepe vnbroken charginge thee moreouer yt thy retourne home thou styrre vp people way neither word writing wise beyng suffered depart luth sent awaye scom wormes gaue glory vnto god way wrote theperour residew prince state repeting whole actio word requiring much hath euer wil seke quiet agrement desireth nothing el yt matter maye indifferently heard iudged scripture wold defende fro force enemy yt priuate cause como al world namely germany whose weale estemeth tha life muche oftentimes mention hath bene made husse counsell constaunce bohemers shall brieflye declare matter iohn wickliffe liued englande yere iohn wicl ffe englishe man lord ccc xciij wrote many thinges agaynst see rome brought afterwardes lade boheme prage noble uniuersitie flourished iohn husse doctor diuinitie lecture sermon set forthe iohn husse bohemer taught wicliffes doctrine holesome godly beyngt accused byshoppe rome alexander fyfte cited procurer sheweth cause coulde come wencelaus also king entreateth requireth would send legate boheme vnderstand matter yt vaine wherefore husse condemned rome heritike setteth forthe writing wherin appealeth bishoppe iudge christ church rome yt time full trouble cardinal husse appealeth pope beyng deuyded chosen three byshoppes gregory xij benedicte xiij iohn xxiij thinge themperor sigismside kynges right sory caused bishop iohn sommon counsell constance sigisinunge brother kynge wencelaus called thither iohn husse sendyng safe conduicte cousel costauce moneth octobre yere mccccxiiij whereupon husse accompanied diuerse gentleman come vnto constance thirde day nouembre three weekes came priuate talke bishop cardinalles deteined prisoner theperour absent beyng certified thing came thyther greate displeasure borne hande promise kept heretikes onely content albeit bohemers made oftentimes greate sute kepe promise also fyrst spak bitterly finally syxt day iuly yere followynge synnode condemned heretike sedicious parson workes also bursit thus beyng condemned deliuered iohn husse hierome praga burned theperour burned ash cast riuer rhine lest reliques shold remayne hierome prage scolar lyke maner executed counsell besydes themperour ambassadours sondry kynges thre prince electours lewes countie palatine raffe duke saxonie fridericke marque brandenburge greate numbre prince three patriarch aquileia antioche costantinople xxviij cardinalles civ byshops diuines lawiers many italian germaines frechmen englishme hugarias polonians doctrine wicliffe condemned decree made body englande taken vp brent furthermore decreed priestes onely receiue hole supper lord al others content one kind thinge husse impugned also lawe made promise kepte heretikes suspected heresye albeit came counsell examined emperours saufeconduicte fynally three byshoppes deposed co mon thre pope deposed assent chosen martin fyfte name whan reported boheme death husse hierome arose tumulte also verye bloudy crewell warre conduicte iohn zischa muche sigysmunde constrayned require aide empire moste crueltie wrought pristes hatred bishop rome whose tirranny shaken receiued doctrine husse time diuines paris condemned luther bokes gatheryng certein title sacramentes diuines paris condempne luth bokes thecclesiastical lawes vowes contrition absolution satisfaction purgatory frewyll suche like admonishyng men professe christ beware suche heretykes vnder flattering wordes exhibite present poyson wiclyffe husse luther thoughe like could see others thoughte christe woulde haue suffered onelye spouse haue wandered longe darkenes errours recytyng bokes shew opinion heretikes luther foloweth wherfore say seyng apperteyneth chiefly professio suppresse errours spring vp finding doctrine pernicious codene bokes brent self forsed recat decree theyrs aunswereth philip melanchthon thauthoritie diuines paris luther selfe skoffyngly notwithstandyng diuines paris take vpon herin chiefe europe haue two principall colledges sorbone nauare bachelars diuinitie exercised disputation somer time space xij houres must answere me argumetes maruelous cotentions part either trifle thinges farre exceadyng man capacitie clamorous aboue measure strife comonly ended hissyng clapping theyr auditor time one disputers either fode tedious doctor diuinitie stade latesse windowes hearke called magistri nostri cesours iudges doctrine plainely possesse kingdo man dare publishe thing touching diuinitie permission leo x swysses make league wyth frenche kynge already made league wt swyses yt nede time shold haue theyr aide kig frauce like case cocluded peace laboured aide wt mony zwinglius sermon diswaded declaringe vnto howe vile howe wicked thing serue foreine prince money exhorted therfore folow frugalitie elder whiche kepte cattel occupied husbandry yet done many goodly exploictes vaine chiefe corrupted wyth bribe perswaded reste make league also kinge aide men saue onely zuricke perswaded zuinglius refused made othe would neuer take wage stypende anye prince serue warres borne kynges sonne charles whome thirtene townes swysses swyces sendynge theyr deputy christened fontestone heluetians swicesse consiste thirtene townes zuricke berne lucerna ura swite unterualde tugie glarea basille solodure friburge schafusiane apecelle ioyned straite leage othe vsynge one law gouerne common theyr common weale fyrst made leage uranites swyces unterualdians tyme expulsynge nobilitie libertie swysses vnder whome oppressed procured owne libertie yere lorde mcccxv came vnto lucerne next tugians syxte place men zuricke last berne basille ioyned wyth societie lawes great frendshippe rhetians lepontians sedunites ueragrites sangallians mullusians rotuuille emperour beyng past one twenty yeres age banisheth luther common decree eyght day may takyng begynning therof owne parson part office luib ontlawed emperour onely establishe augment empire also forese blemishe heresye springe vp within limittes progenitours dede haue bene diligent men herin wherfore mete vnto god hath giuen large ample dominios folow steppe vnlesse punishe nowe heresyes lately spronge vp germany shoulde bothe hurte owne conscience beginning reigne sore blemisshe name dignitie well knowen vnto men wicked doctrine luther hathe spread abroade nowe three foure yeres agaynste byshoppe churche rome decree auncient father namely cou sel constance great reproche theperor sigismude prince germany yt present wherfore syns hys bokes nothing el conteined sedition discorde warre murther mischief yt appereth man wrote rather deuil man likenes zeale beareth common wealth dignitie bishoppe rome doth condemne proscribe aucthor scismes manyfest obstinate heretike commaundynge men vnder great penaltie accepte thre weekes wherin gaue leaue retourne apprehende bringe vnto al shall fauour aide doynges banisheth like case commaundeth also bokes brent appoyntynge greate penaltie herafter stationer commaunding decree sayeth made common consent assent prince well obserued men say decree made fewe diuerse electours confessed made priuie shall declared hereafter archebyshoppe colle archbishoppe mentz beyng chauncelour empire maye muche matter euer came passe emperour hereby wanne muche fauoure muche bishoppe rome cleane forsakynge frenche kynge made league shall declared hereafter tyme publication duke fridericke appointed certein nobilitie especially trusted conueighe luther luth conuetghed daunger way secrete place might eschewe dau ger whiche thinge done bothe diligently closelye carefulnes luther wrote diuerse epistle frendes also bokes concernyng abrogating priuate masse whiche dedicateth sunday bokes luth brother austen freres religious uowes father iohn luther booke agaynst iames latomus doctor louaine austen freres beganne nowe fyrste men leaue massyng cause luther compiled booke might encourage weake confyrme skylfull exhortinge muche perseuer purpose whiche thinge knowen duke friderick fearing great trouble commotion arrise therof commaunded opinion whole uniuersitie herein knowen brought vnto uniuersitie chose iiij purpose iustus ionas themasse abolisshed philip melanchthon nyclas amstorfe iohn dulce conferryng austen freres brought worde theyr intet furthermore declared iniury done lordes supper wherfore beseche prince would abolish great wickednes one churche onely also place set vp trew vse lordes supper accordyng christes commaundement maner apostle stoutly contemnyng al reproches aduersaries hath euerbene sene taketh hande maynteine trew doctrine gospel must suffre many thinges ought greatly foresee accept reuerently present gifte god wherwith chiefly adorned reason lyght ghospell spronge vp amonges people wherunto duke answered would leaue nothing vnattempted might god glory muche thing ful difficultie thinketh good beto hastie litel fewe bringe effect case matter grownded scripture shall doubtles haue mo take theyr part shall alteration shall seme godly necessary conueniently brought passe selfe ignoraunt scripture ca tel time accustomed vse masse reproue came vp yt maner apostle vsed lefte taketh part colledges church fownded mass whiche put downe landes taken awaye geuen purpose euery man might well consyder hurly burly would follow vpon wherfore aduise shalbe go consult matter rest good well learned men vniuersitie theyr heades leyde together suche meanes may foude maye kepe godly quiet men deliberation make answer admoshing put downe masse thinge maye done without tumult thoughe coulde yet whiche righte godlye woulde therfore lefte vndone fewer numbre newes euer syns worlde began greater part men haue resisted trewe doctrine moreouer yt best thiges please fewest men onely shall receiue ryght vse lordes supper vnto whome shall gyuen aboue furthermore colledges fyrst instituted mass youth myght vertuousely brought vp learnynge landes gyuen fynde teach learne reste vse pore vse haue continewed maner time barnarde aboute foure hundreth yeares syns marchaundise mass began whiche vtterly taken awaye albeit originall thereof yet auncient yet great wickednes suffered case busynes shold come therof ought ascribed doctrine wickednes owne lucre impugne truthe conscience ought regard inconueniences procede constantlye trouble euer shall come therof thinges shewed christ thys yeare themperours brother farnando archduke austriche marieth lady anne sister lewes kinge hongary emonges many aduersaries luther henry eyghte kynge englande wrote soore agaynst fyrst confuteth iudgement henry kyng englande writeth luth touching indulgence defendeth bishop authoritie reproueth disputation concerning sacramentes churche taking occasion writing boke intitiled captiuitie babylon whan luther knewe therof answered vehemently shewynge defence cause one whit respecte highnes dignitie parson cause bishop leo gaue kynge honorable title callyng defendour faith howe kynge charles chosen emperour fore declared wheras euer syns certen priuate dyspleasures growe themperor hath warre frauce betwixte hym frenche kynge brake warres fyrst border spaine flaunders tyme frenchman kept parma placence italy bishoppe leo right sory also late attepted rhegium vtterly forsoke entred league emperour wherof chief condicions dignitie churche rome defended suche townes frenchemen late taken recouered france sfortia time banished man restored father seat dukedome millan thus ioyning power together recouered frenchman parma placence force toke citye millan droue french king lumbardy kept quiet possession fullye vi yeares afterwardes restored sfortia conduit prosper columne fernando daualle marque piscare log newes wer brought leo departed without suspicion poysening sone vnto laurens medices death leo x great grandfather cosmus yt great honor house leo made cardinall xiii yeares old liued past seuen forty successor adriane sixt hollader bene tutor emperour time soliman adrian succedeth leo lately created emperour turkes moued warre vpon lewes king boheme hungary maried lady marye themperours sister besides many townes castels tooke turke taketh belgrade belgrade chief fortresse hungary placed therin garrison whilest cesar maketh abode flaunders germany greate sedition arose spaine wherfore intent might remedye thing time hauing first appoynted cousel minister law commotfos spaine see affaire thempire saileth againe spaine toke iorney state thempire readye assembled norinberge concerninge diuers matter chieflye turkyshe warre cesar sending forth proclamation later ende marche warneth chiefly ecclesiasticall parson pray make theyr supplication vnto god afterwardes fyrste maye aide graunted kynge lewes themperour retourne goeth agayne see kynge englande haue assured frende agaynst frenche kynge promyseth geue hym yerely hundreth three thyrtie thousande duckates muche frenchkynge paye yearely kynge englande syster mary french quene wherfore vnlesse mighte saued harmeles would attempt nothing treatie made thirtene day iune castell wyndsore xx myles lodon entiere loue frendship agreed emperour shoulde take wyfe lady mary kynges daughter aunte quene kataryne marry whe lady mart assured theperor time serue seuen yeares age whethersoeuer brake pay foure hundred thousande crownes frenche kynge bendeth force towardes italy recouer lost haue heard zuinglius hugh byshoppe constance within whose prouince zuricke aduertised senate complaintes heard zuinglius kynde newe doctrine broughte defendeth hys cause senate whome satisfied byshoppe wrote letter college canon wherof zuinglius one speakyng muche new doctours troubled churche exhorteth take hede beware muche leo bishop rome emperour also haue streigth proclamation condemned thys doctrine warneth obey neyther alter chaunge thinge till haue authoritie decree thinge generall counsell moneth maye epistle read colledge zuinglius whome concerned wryteth agayne byshop vnderstondeth right well whose motiou doeth admonisheth folow theyr counsell trueth inuincible resysted afterwardes longer letter answereth whiche styrred vp bishoppe write zuinglius certein others intreate bishop letter would hynder doctrine gospell suffer longer filthy sklaunderous life pristes permitte marrye effecte writeth heluetians admonishyng stop course trewe doctrine worke displeasure agaynste maryed author single life priestes single life deuill selfe author many theyr townes maner whan receyue newe minister churche bidde take leman lest attempt defyle honest woman whiche custome althoughe laughed many yet wittelye diuised tyme serued greate darkenes doctrine depraued touchinge theyr concubine ought nowe euery receiued lawfull wine meane tyme luther kepte selfe closse cercertein monethes retorneth wittenberge fearinge lest duke lut rotaurneth wittenberge take euyll part writeth vnto marche signifiyng retourned without commaundement dyd euill wyll contempte knoweth beare hande shall daungerous grace asmuche condemned bothe bishoppe rome themperour whose power bothe great consyder longe ofte three cause retourne fyrst oftentimes requested sundrye letter churche wittenberge retourne whose desyre coulde accomplishe people properly committed charge god ought neglected albeit muche offended refourmation doctrine reporte euill therof yet knoweth moste certenly profession vnto god acceptable secondarely tyme hys absence throughe crafte deuill abyde lyght ghospell styrred vp trouble churche whiche vnlesse selfe present coulde well appeased matter great weightie might wise neglected thinge might haue bene dispatched letter coulde righte easelye haue forborne wittenberge thyrdely sayeth feareth doth maner foresee wo derfull great tempest germany racklesly doeth contemne luther foreseeth teni pest comyng present benefite god many dede embrace trewe doctrine liuyng sklaunder abusynge libertie spirit theyr carnall appetit others wholy gyuen quech oppresse worde rare howe whiche contempte word god must nedes punnishe one plage time past iewes theyr citie hierusalem wherefore part suche others admonishe men hereof whole force diligece albeit trauaile vaine laughed yet may therfore leaue theyr office vndone seyng pleaseth god hathe committed vnto cure soules wherefore prayeth offended thus retourned beyng neither called commaunded sythe altogether christes cause trust shall sustayne displeasure perill retourne trouble whiche absence sayde churche andreas caralostadius meane tyme luther absente preached contrary doctrine disorderlye styrred vp people caste image oute churche cause luther beyng called againe frendes dispraiseth rashenes carolostadius shewyng fyrste image haue bene remoued people hart instructed god pleased image faith onely taken away done magistrate tumulte rage common people tyme began secte saide talke god commaunded sleyng wicked men begin new world wherin onely holy innocent people lyue beare rule kepte selues priuelye parte saronie lyeth riuer sala whose opinion saith luther carolostadius also fauoured could bringe hys matter passe wittenberge beynge defaced luther aucthoritie went then vnto sorte men thomas muncer whiche styrred vp people theyr magistrate thuringe franconie shall recyted place luther hearyng yt lande boheme whiche common assembly counseiled receiue agayne bishop rome luther writeth bohemers aucthoritie elles shoulde neuer ende contention controuersies wryteth vnto moneth auguste name time past odiose hated tyme knewe bishop rome antichriste nowe syns god hath restored worlde lyght gospell iudgeth farre otherwise hath professed workes muche nowe byshoppe clientes much offended aduersaries haue many tymes saied howe fledde boheme dede hath ofte wisshed go thyther lest shoulde call iourney runnynge awaye hath altered purpose nowe matter brought suche passe good hoope howe germaynes bohemers shall professe gospell religion together many sory deuided sectes greued without iuste cause reuolte vnto papistrie shall onely take awaye theyr sectes increase swarme many sectes popish kingdome mo sectes romishe kyngdo sene graye freres differ much amonges themselues yet suche thinges done mainteined byshop rome whose kyngdome throughe men discorde nourished establsshed verye cause whye setteth prince together eares seketh alwaies styrre vp matter grudge displeasure wherfore let take goodhede lest whilest go abolish lesser sectes fal pernicious al romish vtterly vncurable fro thorow god benefit germanye latelye delyuered howe better medicine take awaye euill pastours churche woulde setforth doctrine gospell purely syncerely case reteyne weake people theyr dewtie wyll reuolte lest wyse let indeuour kepe styl lordes supper wholy memoriall husse hierome prage vndetiled may bishop attempt take two thinges chiefly wherfore relent graunr tyrant bothe shall well done howe though boheme reuolte yet set forth commende doctrine husse vnto posteritie wherfore praieth exhorteth perseuer state religion whiche haue defended muche bloud valeauntnes neither yng blemishe gospell nowe florisheth beit al thinges wel established amonges yet god fayle whan seeth time styrre vp faythfull minister reforme religion wyll constant vtterly refuse fylthines wickednes romisshe bishoppe concernyng bohemers thus standeth death iohn husse people boheme wer deuided three sectes bohemers three sectes oue part toke bishoppe rome head churche uicar christ another sorte receyued lordes suppes kyndes mass certeine thynges rehersed vulgare tounge differing nothing el papistes thyrde sort called picardes call bishop rome antichriste whore babilon described reuelation admitte nothynge bible chose theyr owne priestes bishoppes forbid man mary pray dead holy dayes ceremony haue fewe luther compiled boke againste false named order lu writeth againste bishoppes bishop preface wherof saith great shame many great liuinges honourable title prosessyng maisters whole scripture yt dare come dispute onelye indifferent iudges beyng ofte prouoked therunto wherfore saieth hence forth submitte writynges vnto dyd wormes doctrine christes lyueth reigneth euer restraine theyr madnes bluddye enterprise decree bishop rome theperor name marke great beast taken thaketh god highly hath deliuered stiking dogeon filthy error wicked doctrine lightened trewe knowledge worde wherof certein yt herafter submit doctrine iudgement angell testimony therof iudge selfe angel also wherfore warneth put trust theyr tyrany swell theyr malice enuie hym boldely proceds purpose christ liueth reygneth confounde cruell bloddy enterprise would wishe dede theyr amendment yt wil wil haue continual warre shall neuer recociled charge franke rebuking shuld styrre vp people muche wronge proued scripture yt reprehesions necessary pastor church bevnlearned wicked obstinate neither doynge dutie theselues permitting others yt would right well cousel norinberge lewis king hugary sent ambassador lametably coplaining turkes great crueltie desyred stroge cotinual aide thither sent also adria bishop adrian writeth duke sa rome hierome rorare one chaberlaines letter duke friderike signifiyng yt right glad heare thassebly norinberge trusting yt shalbe thing done yt shall cocerne co mon weale cause hath also determined cosent cardinal tosed ambassador thither yt meane thought good sede signifie vnto hath euermore loued derely good affectio towardes common wealth shall better know ambassador yt foloweth exhorteth praieth hi yt price thepire tuition empire church rome cosisteth wold trauaile cosult diligetly thing yt cocerne dignitie thapostolical church traquilitie comon weale folow herein steppe noble progenitor desyringe giue credite ierome suche thynges hath wylled debate wt farnado archduke austriche straight executer sentece giuen yere luther dukedome wittenberge helde time set forth sore proclamation xxvj day nouebre promisyng rewardes promotors prouinces punished extremely yt obeied pope lawes reucline dieth yere departed reucline pure aged man erasmus roterodame commended goodly dialoge attributyng vnto hym immortalitie excellencie knowledge three tonges latter ende nouembre adrian bishop rome sendeth letter whole assemblie norinberge sin time pope writeth letter prince germany first chosen thoffice apostleship neuer wished thinge yt might euery codition accomplish dewtie good pastour suffring one shepe flocke go farre stray asmuch might done vigilant eye carefulnes herof taketh god witnes hath auaunced vnworthy dignitie neuer loked intent might easely atteine purpose hath greatly exhorted kynges prince absteine fro ciuil warres nedes make warre bende theyr forse power againste enemy christian faith yt assaied perswade others hathe performed self hauing sent great sum money knight rhodes present great daunger theperor turkes afterwardes calling home remebrauce forein periles loking narrowly vpo domestical euils heareth great discofort yt martin luther hath oftetimes bene gently fatherly admonished length whan none remedy co demned banisshed certein uniuersities leo predecessor also themperor comon cosent yet put silece styll libertie setting forth dayly new bokes christia religio al honest liuing sore decaied thing greueth hi much heareth saye howe diuerse nobilitie fauoure hym matter farre gone ecclesiasticall parson dauger lose lades dignitie germany touching ye thing certein haue already styrred vp ciuil war corin trewly spoke paule yt iiedes must heresy thinges stad chauseth ceason deuill disposed wrap v sondry calamity one time instigation fury turkes heresie luth oppresse v although v possible discofite foreine enemie yet log domestical aduersarie vnuaquished litel preuaile time yet spaine hearde muche luther false opinion albeit greued yt euyl shold spring countrey borne yet comfort self wt ij thing fyrst truste trifelynge wicked doctrine haue bene dispised men secondely suche pestilente plante broughte place lightly take roote countrie whiche alwayes ingendred roters heresyes hath chau sed otherwise whether iust iudgement god throughe certeine negligence racklesnes suche shoulde haue redressed tyme uerelye nede looke lest whilest worke slowlye herin appere eyther haue forgotten olde vertue el approue wickednes alledgyng amonges thynges shame stronge constaunt nation swarue religion whiche christ apostle haue lefte v whiche many martyr notable person also forefather haue kept obserued motion sory frere hathe folowed professed selfe many yeres thoughe erred luther frere many hundreth yeres though christ hath promised euer amonges v woulde haue suffered churche remayne log errours thoughe onely wise styrred vp god intent open errour whole worlde thinges doubtles wise mockerye laughed haue deuilish purpose vnder pretence christia libertie may contemne lawe rule aucthoritie work outrage lyst seyng haue already comitted sacrilege vnreuerently handled lawes holy bishoppes counsel yea cast fyre thinke wyll knowe obey ciuill magistrate haue begon sley priestes enter vpon possession wil fine ende theyr mischeuous enterprise prince themselues theyr wiues childre family wherfore praieth exhorteth aucthoritie office beareth successour peter christes vicar also chargeth commaundeth layinge displeasure part newe reconciled mindes come wholye together quenche comon domestical flame punishing luther amende according new decre made theperor folowyng herin thexample theyr elder cousell costance burned iohn husse hierome prage wel deserued whose vertu case nowe would imitate god faile might also hope giue repulse turke violence wil bestowe treasure yea hys lyfe also flocke committed charge rest concernynge luther shall knowe hys legate fraunces cheregate byshoppe aprutia vnto whome prayeth gyue credite ciuill warre spake betwyxte rycharde warre treuers archebyshoppe treuers fraunces sickynge noble man fauoured luther muche notwithstandynge cause warre religion bicause bishop would suffer two men wythin hys iurisdiction whome became suertie aunswere law mentioneth writyng wherin fraunces sente hym defiaunce aboute latter ende auguste byshop adrian wrote letter effect certein others also greatlye detested doctrine luther required senate strasbourge suffer bookes pope letter strasburge adherentes printed suche set forthe already shoulde onely suppresse burne also heareth say howe suche maner bookes put print theyr men contrary workes refused whereunto vnlesse obey threateneth wrath vengeaunce god although perseuer neuer much olde religion yet vnlesse take others libertie offende occasyon errour let loke scape vnpunished saieth whilest spaine hearde luther thus standeth stocke aorian adrian poore man sonne utrecht egge hollande learninge whiche gote uniuersitie louain called scolemaster charles nowe emperour afterwardes beyng sent ambassadoure spaine obteyned bishopricke derthuse kyng ferdinando whose death gouernement came vnto kyng charles remayned chiefe counsel time bishoppe leo dissention betwixt leo cardinal fell variaunce cardinal conspired death muche dispatched many exile imprisonnement made one thirtie newe cardinal one tyme partly owne defence partly get money amonges adriane one afterwardes whilest emperour wet crowned germany gouernemet spaine absens whan leo tenth died wheras iulius medices alexander farnesius laboured excendyngly adriane beyng absent vnknowen chosen bishoppe ix daye ianuary yeare lorde thousande fyue hundred twenty two hearinge thereof wrote letter thanckes colledge cardinalles good opinion whereas iii cardinal appointed sent ambassadours spaine willeth spare theyr paynes shortly may come rome selfe writeth moreouer senate people rome litel displeased straunger shoulde haue dignitie promisinge soeuer pleasure could shew fewe monethes chaunsynge fayre wynde taketh shyppynge italy arryueth rome monthe august beit tyme cesar commynge flaunders appease rebellyon arryued spaine yet departed neuer bad hym fare well wrote vnto hym gentell letter signifiyng great hast time soliman emperor turkes besieged rhodes three monethes seuenth moneth knightes defended selues valeauntly beyng destitute aide succor toke coposition xxv dece ber onely oure great losse
